video.title: Banishers: Ghosts of New Eden | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Banishers (HURK) Ghosts of New Eden comes 
to us from the bods who brought us Vampyr,

that game from a few years back you may 
recall was a gloomy, slightly overambitious

open world action RPG centred around a dodgy 
moral dilemma and unavoidable token combat

about as fun as squeezing pus out of a 
semi-healed wound and using it to fill

out your tax return. So Banishers has come a 
long way since then. It&#39;s about a different

standard Halloween monster now. See if you 
can guess which one. It&#39;s set in a Puritan

settlement in 17th century New England. Bearing 
that in mind, what specific variety of standard

Halloween monster do you think we&#39;ll be mostly 
concerned with? Think carefully. What kind of

supernatural entities are 17th century Puritans 
famous for overzealously hunting? In the sort of

hunts certain former presidents have a tendency 
to ceaselessly bang on about? That&#39;s right:

ghosts. Banishers (HURK) Ghosts of New 
Eden is about tracking down, identifying,

exorcising and beating the slightly-see-through 
snot out of ghosts. What, were you expecting

witches? Ha ha ha don&#39;t be silly. There aren&#39;t any 
witches in Banishers (HURK) Ghosts of New Eden,

except for several. Oh, and some of the 
ghosts are ghosts of witches. But come on,

it&#39;s 17th century New England, a few of them 
were going to be anyway, that&#39;s just statistics.

Our two protagonists cover pretty much the 
entire spectrum of race, gender and competence:

Antea Duarte, experienced Cuban ghost hunter, 
and her Scottish apprentice Red Rory MacReith,

a rambunctious rogue resigned to regularly 
ruffle rhotacisms with his rubric. Antea and

Red have that rare dynamic in games - an actual 
established couple, rather than boy and girl

thrown together by circumstance whose firm mutual 
contempt is one climax and beautiful sunset away

from clumsily transitioning to Snogtown, north of 
Titgrope. These heroes are in a loving, mutually

comfortable relationship between equals, so you 
know what that means - things are going to very

swiftly go to shit. They show up to the colony 
of New Eden - which, in terms of tempting fate,

is a name right up there with &quot;Nothing Bad 
Ever Happens Here Ville&quot; - to exorcise the evil

ghosts who are bringing the property values 
down, only for things to inevitably barrel

shitwards when the main ghost - not strictly 
a witch but definitely witch-adjacent - proves

more powerful than they thought, leaving 
Red half dead and Antea all the way dead.

But Antea comes back as a ghost so she 
can guide Red across the island through

a bunch of easier training exorcisms before 
they jump straight to the final exam again,

and from this springs the central 
dilemma. At the end of their journey,

will Red exorcise Antea and send her spirit 
on in accordance with his duty as a Banisher,

or will he try to bring her back to life with a 
forbidden ritual that entails murdering a bunch of

people. Um. It&#39;s not *much* of a moral dilemma, is 
it? Maybe if we hadn&#39;t spent the entire prologue

hammering on the point that hanging around after 
your death is unnatural and wrong and really

brings the atmosphere down at parties, but the 
whole &quot;murder several innocents&quot; strategy really

doesn&#39;t help the case. Seems pretty bloody obvious 
which course of action is less likely to backfire,

narratively speaking. Maybe we&#39;re supposed to 
be really invested in their relationship. Main

sticking point with that though: I wasn&#39;t. The 
screen isn&#39;t exactly aglow with white-hot passion.

Antea mostly treats Red with the sort of loving 
condescension one extends to a German Shepherd

and Red is a bearded aggressively Scottish dude 
in a tartan kilt stopping just short of drying

his tears on a set of bagpipes and I feel like 
he&#39;s a big enough boy to get by on his own now.

Thinking about it, the choice would&#39;ve been much 
harder if Red had been a German shepherd. All

he&#39;d have to do is look at her body and then 
to camera with a big soppy look on his face

and I for one would probably have to reassess 
the murder a bunch of dudes proposal. Ooh! A

German shepherd wearing a little tam o&#39;shanter. 
Fuck, I&#39;d start killing people BEFORE he did the

face. But anyway. Ghost hunting doesn&#39;t strike 
me as having much potential as a game mechanic,

going by reality TV shows at least, seems 
to largely involve overreacting to faint

creaking noises and getting really excited about 
specks of dust in the camera lens. In Varnishers:

Dust On New Furniture the ghost hunting process 
starts when you find someone acting sullen or

aggressive in a way that isn&#39;t adequately 
explained by them living in 17th century

New England surrounded by Puritans who&#39;ll burn 
them at the stake if they smile too much. Then

you explore their house to find clues such as 
diary pages reading &quot;I&#39;m so glad I murdered

my husband and got away with it, tee hee 
hee.&quot; Which are usually cunningly hidden

out in the open on a kitchen table under 
an enormous flashing objective marker.

So the core gameplay isn&#39;t so much about 
clever deduction as smacking the ectoplasmic

shit out of angry ghosts in the token combat 
that will occur at more or less this point,

either an angry ghost in some way related to the 
current mystery, or just some generic angry ghosts

who happen to be around and don&#39;t have anything 
else on. So combat&#39;s a largely melee-focussed,

prioritising targets affair in which 
we switch at will between ghost Antea,

who has better mobility and doesn&#39;t die from 
running out of health, and non-ghost Red,

who has a big fucking sword, that actually 
does damage and means you don&#39;t have to

pick away at spongy health bars with your tiny 
semi-transparent fists. The character switching

adds some vaguely interesting nuance beyond the 
usual dodge some things and parry other things,

but suffers from spongeyness, lack of enemy 
variety - who&#39;s your favourite, the white ghost,

the green ghost, or the big fat red ghost with 
the attack telegraphs longer than an episode

of Midsomer Murders - and a general sense of 
being irrelevant busywork, especially when

you&#39;re randomly waylaid on your way somewhere 
by four generic ghosts who&#39;ve gone all in on

haunting this highly specific ten square yards 
of unkept grass, turns into it a bit of a chore.

The three or four story boss fights liven 
it up a bit, but half the time don&#39;t feel

like tests of the skills we&#39;ve been 
developing in the generic combat,

the first boss seems endlessly bewildered by my 
ability to dodge out of the way of its charge,

turn around and pop it in the bum. And speaking 
of bottoms, once you&#39;ve gotten to the bottom of

who&#39;s haunting who and why you confront the 
hauntee and then the moral dilemma comes up

again as we must decide whether to exorcise the 
spirit, exorcise the spirit in a mean voice,

or kill the haunted person by accusing them 
of bad deeds so hard their head explodes or

something. It&#39;s not really a choice because 
exorcising very overtly leads to Antea&#39;s

ascension ending and blame murder towards 
the highly suspect resurrection ending,

so sometimes the hauntee actually deserves to 
get blamesploded and I&#39;d have to absolve them

anyway because I&#39;m not stupid, there&#39;s never any 
benefit to flipflopping, I know, I played both

Infamous games AND the shitty one. Funny how 
Dontnod have now made two games whose stories

both crucially hinge upon a gamelong moral dilemma 
that completely falls apart on examination. Maybe

they should process this in therapy. Maybe they 
were molested as a child by John Stuart Mill.
